newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait prosecutor wants death in MP killing bid.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait prosecutor wants death in MP killing bid.

text.p: Kuwait's prosecution on Tuesday sought death sentences against three Kuwaitis and two Iranians who denied involvement in a failed bid to kill an opposition MP.
"The Prosecution General demands the imposition of the maximum penalty...," prosecutor Adel al-Juwai'ed told a criminal court on the first hearing of the case. "The punishment is execution," he said.

Kuwaiti defendants Salman Ahmad al-Shamlan, 41, Abdul-Mohsen al-Roumi, 37, Adel Mohammad al-Mchaimi, 42, and Iranian Sayed Abdul-Hadi Sayed Ali Ardabili, 19, denied charges of attempting to kill leading liberal MP Abdullah al-Naibari and his wife.

Iranian defendant Sayed Mohammad Sayed Ali Ardabili, 25, told Judge Ibrahim al-Obeid in Arabic: "The intention was different," commenting on the attempted murder charge, while Mchaimi told the court he took Naibari to hospital.

Gunmen ambushed Naibari's car on June 6 as he drove in a southern beach area. Naibari, 61, is receiving medical attention in the United States for wounds in the jaw and shoulder, while his wife suffered a superficial bullet wound near her left shoulder.

"There were political pressures in this case...because Naibari is a member of the National Assembly," said Najib al-Wougayan, defence lawyer for Roumi. "I was prevented from attending the investigation," he added without elaboration.
"They (investigators) were influenced by the spotlights," he said.
The court turned down a request to release Roumi on bail and set August 26 for a second hearing to allow lawyers to review the case documents. The five defendants are detained.

Mohsen al-Mutairi, a member of Naibari's lawyers team, asked the court to allow Kuwait University specialists to examine the bullets used in the attack because Naibari "has suffered a form of undetermined poisoning". He did not explain.
Mutairi demanded a preliminary compensation of 500,000 dinars ($1.64 million), while a lawyer representing Furaih demanded 5,001 dinars also as a preliminary compensation.
Several MPs linked the attack to parliament's relentless questioning about financial scandals in which they claim former officials mismanaged and squandered public funds.
The government has urged parliament to avoid triggering an internal strife over the attempt, saying there was no evidence that the attack was politically motivated.
Naibari played a key role in parliamentary efforts to combat what some MPs described as graft at state-run institutions.
